title: Force on current - circular loop in magnetic field

content.question: A uniform magnetic field <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> is directed toward the top of the page, as shown. A circular loop of radius <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> carries a current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> counterclockwise. Which of the following correctly shows the sum of forces that the magnetic field exerts on the loop with the correct reasoning?

choices.label: <math alttext="F sub net equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>net</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, because each segment of wire has a matching segment on the opposite side with current going in the opposite direction.

<math alttext="F sub net equals I pi times R squared B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>net</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>I</mi><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>B</mi></math>, because the loop is in the plane of the field.

<math alttext="F sub net equals I pi times R B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>net</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>I</mi><mi>π</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>B</mi></math>, because half of the circular loop contributes to the sum of the forces.

<math alttext="F sub net equals I 2 times pi R B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>net</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>B</mi></math>, because every segment of the loop contributes the same amount of force.

content.answer: <math alttext="F sub net equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>net</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, because each segment of wire has a matching segment on the opposite side with current going in the opposite direction.
